body:
@SamStephens Unfortunately, I cannot repro this:

```ts
Middle click brings up a new tab with a blank page
https://researchglobal0.bmocapitalmarkets.com/research/45c0f894-778e-4557-a4a8-4962d29f6da9/ - BMO Capital Markets
Normal click navigates successfully
https://researchglobal0.bmocapitalmarkets.com/research/45c0f894-778e-4557-a4a8-4962d29f6da9/ - BMO Capital Markets
```

> @SamStephens Unfortunately, I cannot repro this:
> 
> ```ts
> Middle click brings up a new tab with a blank page
> https://researchglobal0.bmocapitalmarkets.com/research/45c0f894-778e-4557-a4a8-4962d29f6da9/ - BMO Capital Markets
> Normal click navigates successfully
> https://researchglobal0.bmocapitalmarkets.com/research/45c0f894-778e-4557-a4a8-4962d29f6da9/ - BMO Capital Markets
> ```

@dgozman that's unfortunate. I just re-tested and re-confirmed.

```
Middle click brings up a new tab with a blank page
about:blank -
Normal click navigates successfully
https://researchglobal0.bmocapitalmarkets.com/research/e04fc1f8-b263-4169-adab-f72f21dd730a/ - BMO Capital Markets
```

I guess this must be some form of timing issue. Factors that could be at play here:

* I'm in New Zealand, so latency could be a factor.
* I'm running from WSL 2 (Ubuntu running on Windows 11).
* My machine is pretty grunty, AMD Ryzen 9 5900X and 32 GB of RAM.
@SamStephens Turns out, I was running headed and it works in headed. However, I can repro in headless, so we'll take a look.

@SamStephens I looked into this in details, and the new tab opens in headless as well. However, it opens with `about:blank` url first, and then navigates to the desired url. I'd recommend to wait for a particular url instead of calling `wait_for_load_state()`:


```py
            new_page = new_page_info.value
            try:
                # Do not wait for the load state
                # new_page.wait_for_load_state()

                # Wait for the url instead
                new_page.wait_for_url('https://researchglobal0.bmocapitalmarkets.com/research/45c0f894-778e-4557-a4a8-4962d29f6da9/')

                # If you do not know the exact url, wait for a pattern
                new_page.wait_for_url('https://researchglobal0.bmocapitalmarkets.com/**/*')

                print("Middle click brings up a new tab with a blank page")
                print(f"{new_page.url} - {new_page.title()}")
            finally:
                new_page.close()
```

Let me know whether that works for you.

@dgozman works like a dream. Actually for my real world use case, I don't even need that, because the first thing I try and do with my new page is wait for a locator that tells me loading activity on the page is finished.

I guess the question is whether the issue is just me coming into this with the wrong expectations, or whether this behavior should be talked about in the documentation, maybe as part of https://playwright.dev/docs/pages#handling-new-pages ?

issue.title: docs: do not recommend waitForLoadState

repository.name: playwright
repository.description: Playwright is a framework for Web Testing and Automation. It allows testing Chromium, Firefox and WebKit with a single API.

issue.body:
Instead, just perform an action and auto-waiting will handle it.

Closes #30236.

body: @dgozman what you've done is good, but I wonder if it's also calling out in https://playwright.dev/docs/pages#handling-new-pages that when a new page is opened, you cannot reliably waitForLoadState because of the about:config thing. With the documentation change you've made, I'd still have done exactly the same thing, because I was doing this before I actually scripted any actions against the new page, I was just testing `click(button='middle')` would successfully open the link in a new page.

@SamStephens Since the problem only arises in chromium headless in limited circumstances like middle-click, I think it would be too specific to be called out in the docs. This github issue serves as a good enough documentation source for anyone stumbling upon this problem, which I think would be very rare. If we see more folks having trouble with this scenario, we'll reconsider.
